'''Narn i Hîn Húrin''' ([[Sindarin]] for "'''Tale of the Children of Húrin'''")
column4: a posthumously published work of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] edited and published by [[Christopher Tolkien]]. It is a long story of all that happened to [[Húrin]] and his children [[Túrin]] and [[Nienor]]
column5: after Húrin was cursed by [[Morgoth]]. In 2007
column6: Christopher Tolkien published ''[[The Children of Húrin]]''
column7: wherein Tolkien completed the story and completed a single narrative of this tale with minimal editorial presence.

column1: The story elaborates on what is told of these characters in the published ''[[The Silmarillion]]''
column2: starting with the childhood of Túrin
column3: continuing through the captivity of his father in the [[Nirnaeth Arnoediad]]
column5: to Túrin's time in [[Nargothrond]] and ending with his suicide after having slain [[Glaurung]].

column1: The story has some inconsistencies when compared with ''The Silmarillion''
column2: and at points there are gaps and multiple versions. This is because [[J.R.R. Tolkien|Tolkien]] never finished the story during his lifetime
column3: and his son [[Christopher Tolkien]] had to choose from all the work to create a consistent narrative for ''The Silmarillion''.

column1: The story of the ''Narn'' continues in the ''Later Narn''
column4: a text which was found to be too different in style from the rest of ''The Silmarillion''
column5: but which continues the ''Narn'' after Túrin's death. It ends with Húrin's eventual release and the bad deeds which follow him. This story was finally published in ''[[The War of the Jewels]]''.

column1: Note that the title of the ''Narn'' is wrongly given as '''Narn i Hîn Húrin''' in the published ''Silmarillion'' and ''Unfinished Tales''. This was an editorial decision by [[Christopher Tolkien]] which he later regretted
column2: done only to prevent people from pronouncing ''[[Hîn|Chîn]]'' like the English "chin".<ref>{{LR|Quenta}}
